Main Page: Titles of European hereditary rulers

Last updated: Nov 29, 2023

Franche-Comté / Burgundy Palatine

Overview.

After the division of the Carolingian Empire in the 9th century, the County of Burgundy Palatine (Franche-Comté) became a part of the Kingdom of Arles / Burgundy.

In 1032, the County of Burgundy Palatine (Franche-Comté) joined the Holy Roman Empire, when the Roman Emperor Conrad II inherited the Kingdom of Arles / Burgundy.

In 1384, the County of Burgundy Palatine (Franche-Comté) passed to Margaret, wife of Philip "the Bold", Duke of Burgundy.

In 1477, after the death of Duke Charles "the Bold" of Burgundy, King Louis XI of France seized Franche-Comté from Charles' daughter Mary.

In 1493, by the Treaty of Senlis the King of France ceded the County of Burgundy Palatine (Franche-Comté) to the House of Austria (the Habsburgs) who in the 16th century inherited Spain.

In 1668, the French occupied the County of Burgundy Palatine (Franche-Comté), but soon gave up the land by the Treaty of Aix-la-Chapelle (May 1668).

In 1674, the French occupied the County of Burgundy Palatine (Franche-Comté).

In 1678, by the Treaty of Nijmegen, King Philip IV of Spain, who was the last Count of Burgundy, ceded Franche-Comté to the King of France.

Notes.

1. In the 16th-17th centuries, Franche-Comté was included with Luxembourg and the Low Countries in the Burgundian Imperial Circle of the Holy Roman Empire.

Geographical names.

Alsace -> Elsass (in Haut-Rhin and Bas-Rhin, Grand Est, France).

Artois (in Hauts-de-France., France).

Austria -> Österreich.

Baugé [en-Bresse] -> Bâgé-le-Châtel; Baugé le Chastel; Villa Baugiaci Castri (in Ain, Auvergne-Rhône-Alpes, France).

Burgundy -> Burgundia; Bourgogne (in Bourgogne-Franche-Comté, , France).

Burgundy Palatine -> Franche-Comté (in Bourgogne-Franche-Comté, France).

Carinthia -> Kärnten (in Austria and Slovenia).

Carniola -> Krain (in Slovenia).

Chalon-sur-Saône (in Saône-et-Loire, Bourgogne-Franche-Comté, France).

Charolais (in Saône-et-Loire, Bourgogne-Franche-Comté, France).

Château-Chinon (in la Nièvre, Bourgogne-Franche-Comté, France).

Ferrette -> Pfirt (in Haut-Rhin, Alsace, France).

Flanders -> Vlaenderen (in Belgium).

Habsburg (in Aargau, Switzerland).

Kyburg (in Zurich, Switzerland).

Mechelen / Mecheln / Mechlin -> Malines (in Antwerpen, Vlaenderen, Belgium).

Nevers (in Nièvre, Bourgogne-Franche-Comté, France).

Pordenone -> Portus Naonis; Portenau (in Friuli-Venezia Giulia, Italy).

Styria -> Steiermark (in Austria and in Slovenia).

Rethel (in Ardennes; Champagne-Ardenne, France).

Salins (-les-Bains) -> Salinarum (in Jura, Bourgogne-Franche-Comté, France).

The Wendish March -> Marchia Sclavonice, Windischen Mark (in Slovenia).

Chistian (First) names.

Charles -> Carolus.

John -> Johannes; Jean,

Joan -> Johanna; Jeanne.

Louis -> Ludovicus.

Odo -> Eudes.

Otto -> Othon.

- [1248] Merania

With the death of Otto III, the House of Andechs, became extinct in the male line, and the title of Duke of Merania expired; Franche-Comté passed to Otto's sister Adelaide (1248).

Appendix 1. Auxonne

Overview.

William (+1157), brother of Count Rainald / Reginald of Burgundy (+1148), received Auxonne.

William's descendants ruled in Auxonne until 1237, when John (+1267) exchanged Auxonne and Chalon for the Lordship of Salins with the Duke of Burgundy [19: tome XV (1899); p.152; Doc.# VIII].
